    		University Funding Sources
    	General Operating FundsSpecial Operating FundsOther FundsAuxiliary Organization FundsGeneral Operating FundGeneral Fund (PDF)The CSU Operating Fund is used to report revenues, expenses and net assets related to state-supported instruction, related programs, and operations.22/23 Funding: $243 MillionStudent Learning Fee(SLF)(opens in new window)Campus Based Mandatory Fee: Authorized by EO 1049.22/23 Funding: $2.48 MillionConsolidated Course Fee (CCF) (PDF)Campus Based Mandatory Fee: Authorized by EO 1049.22/23 Funding: $364,000Miscellaneous Course Fee (MCF)(opens in new window)Category III Fee: Authorized by EO 1102.22/23 Funding: $200,000Graduate Business Professional Fee (MBA Fee)(opens in new window)Category I Fee: Authorized by EO 1102.22/23 Funding: $250,000Health Services Fee(opens in new window)Category II Fee: Authorized by EO 1102.22/23 Funding: $7 MillionSpecial Operating FundsCOAST (Council On Ocean Affairs, Science, and Technology)(opens in new window)System-wide resources and promotion of interdisciplinary multi-campus collaborations to advance our knowledge of natural coast and marine resources and processes that affect them.Fund: T8511ARI (Agriculture Research Institute)(opens in new window)Research and technology transfer activities complement the basic research conducted by the nation's land-grant universities and aim to improve the economic viability and sustainability of California agriculture.Fund: T8512WRPI (Water Resources and Policy Initiatives)(opens in new window)Develops water management solutions through research, partnership, education and training that provides students with hands-on learning.Fund: T8514CSUPERB (CSU Program for Education and Research in Biotechnology)(opens in new window)Develops professional biotechnology workforce by mobilizing and supporting collaborative CSU students and faculty research, innovating education practices, and responding to and anticipating the needs of the life science industry.Fund: T8510RSCA (Research Scholarly, and Creative Awards)(opens in new window)These funds are only to be used in support of faculty research, scholarly and creative activities in accordance with article 25.6 of the collective bargaining agreement.Fund: T8515Other FundsLottery(opens in new window)Generated from the sale of California State Lottery tickets, a portion of which is allocated to CSU campuses. Lottery funds must be used for instructional purposes only and must not supplement state funding of instruction.22/23 Funding: $1.6 MillionIRA (Instructionally Related Activities)(opens in new window)Generated by mandatory fees paid by all students as a part of their registration fees. These funds are used for out-of-classroom activities and experiences integrally related to the instructional offering, including athletics and recreational sports.22/23 Funding: $5.5 MillionCERF (Continuing Education Funds)(opens in new window)Continuing Education Operating Fund and is comprised of the campus-approved per unit fees collected from students enrolling in self-support course offerings through Regional & Continuing Education.22/23 Funding: $9.5 MillionFund: C3181Campus Partners (PDF)Calculated distribution of the fee revenue collected through Continuing Education (RCE), distributed back to the colleges and the Provost's office and used as a supplemental funding source to enhance self-support programs.22/23 Funding:  Percentage of RCE RevenueFund: C4401Parking(opens in new window)Campus parking facilities are not supported by taxpayer dollar but are instead self-supporting. They are paid for by the users of the facilities through payment of parking fees.22/23 Funding: $990,000Housing(opens in new window)Funds generated from student fees for residence hall living/learning experiences. Housing operations are considered self-supporting and not supported by taxpayer dollars.22/23 Funding: $22.3 MillionMiscellaneous Trust Funds These trust funds include various quasi-self-support activities that operate in tangent with the CSU operating fund. They include separate revenue sources that are not related to state support or student fees.Auxiliary Organization FundsAssociated Students (AS)(opens in new window)Under a student government umbrella, operates the bookstore, dining services, student union and student programs.22/23 Funding: $22.5 MillionUniversity Foundation (UF)(opens in new window)Responsible for solicitation, acceptance, and administration of gifts to the University.22/23 Funding: $9 MillionChico State EnterprisesDevelops and manages grants and contracts, campus centers and programs, enterprise projects and provides financial administrative services to the University Foundation.22/23 Funding: $45.2 MillionDivision of Business & FinanceVice President for Business & FinanceZip Code: 95929-0025www.csuchico.edu/vpbfDepartmentsAudit ServicesDistribution ServicesEnvironmental Health and SafetyFacilities Management and ServicesFinancial ServicesHuman Resources Service CenterProcurement & Contract ServicesRisk ManagementStaff CouncilUniversity Budget OfficeUniversity Police
We acknowledge and are mindful that Chico State stands on lands that were originally occupied by the first people of this area, Mechoopda, and we recognize their distinctive spiritual relationship with this land, the flora, the fauna, and the waters that run through campus. We are humbled that our campus resides upon sacred lands that since time immemorial have sustained the Mechoopda people and continue to do so today.Contact UsNeed Help?FacebookFacebookTwitterTwitterInstagramInstagramReport an accessibility issueReport a broken link on this pageTitle IXPrivacy PolicyCalifornia State University, Chico400 West First StreetChico, CA 95929Copyright © 2023 All Rights Reserved
